results.doc_title: LEGO: Unified Prospects Checkout Features and Layout for Meal Brands
results.summary: LEGO is an initiative to create a unified prospects checkout experience across all HelloFresh Group meal brands (HelloFresh, GreenChef, EveryPlate, ChefsPlate, Factor, and Youfoodz). The project involves modularizing checkout code into reusable unified features and implementing a standardized layout to improve scalability and reduce development effort across 31 distinct codebases spanning 18 countries. Most features have been rolled out, with the unified Lego Checkout layout completed for HelloFresh and meal brands.
key_points: Goal is to unify checkout experience across 8 brands in 18 countries using modular, reusable features
Checkout ownership transferred to Growth Alliance in January 2025, expanding scope to 31 distinct codes
Most checkout features (Order Summary, Register Form, Address Form, Delivery Details, Payment Methods) have been rolled out across brands
Unified Lego Checkout layout has been completed and rolled out for HelloFresh and meal brands
Initiative aims to accelerate product development velocity and reduce isolated work efforts
Social Logins Feature showed neutral results for RTE/WLMK brands with no rollout planned
NV (accounting for ~$250M annual revenue) was not included in original scope but could potentially adopt Lego with additional work
decisions: Social Logins Feature will not be rolled out to RTE/WLMK brands due to neutral experiment results
Rollout decision for US experiment to be made mid-March
Checkout ownership centralized within Growth Alliance as of January 2025
action_items: Complete UFI-9680: Integrate with New Progress bar (ETA Mar 28, 2025)
Complete UFI-9678: Remove invalid voucher from payload after first checkout attempt (ETA Mar 28, 2025)
Complete UFI-9682: Add check for logged-in user/cart-id and redirect (ETA Mar 28, 2025)
Check requirement for CTA sticky-ness (UFI-9693) - Not Started
@anupam.maurya@hellofresh.com to add tickets for items to be moved to Features
@anupam.maurya@hellofresh.com to confirm layout work includes necessary components and add spike
@harneet.singh@hellofresh.com to provide status update

results.doc_title: IXI Results: Creator Marketplace Customer Interviews
results.summary: Research participants responded positively to HelloFresh's Influencer Marketplace concept, which addresses friction points in sourcing niche ingredients and managing saved recipes. However, trust is driven by practical signals rather than influencer status, with users expecting HelloFresh to vet recipes or provide transparent community ratings. The marketplace is viewed as occasion-based rather than for everyday meal planning, with users preferring one-time purchases over subscriptions and food-first discovery over creator-led browsing.
key_points: Users view the marketplace as a solution for turning social media food inspiration into achievable home cooking, addressing ingredient sourcing difficulties and forgotten saved recipes
Trust in recipes depends on practical signals (visuals, clear instructions, original content access) rather than influencer status alone
Participants expect HelloFresh to ensure recipe quality through internal testing or transparent community ratings and reviews
The marketplace is perceived as occasion-based (weekends, hosting, special dinners) rather than a replacement for everyday meal planning
Users strongly prefer one-time purchases over subscription requirements to lower barriers to trial
Discovery should be food-first (by ingredient/cuisine) rather than creator-led (by influencer names)
Users need robust recipe management tools including custom organization and scheduling features
decisions: Recommendation to include direct links to original social media videos on recipe pages
Recommendation to implement a verified badge system for HelloFresh-tested recipes
Recommendation to provide unfiltered reviews with ratings, feedback, and photos
Recommendation to add a comment or Q&A section separate from reviews
Recommendation to offer one-time purchase options rather than forcing subscriptions
action_items: Forward verified badge idea to DAU team (mentioned by katheryn.eckles@hellofresh.com)
Determine actual value proposition: if not influencers, consider why not just offer one-time purchase in HelloFresh instead of separate marketplace
Create video clips showing user assumptions about HelloFresh responsibility and ratings/reviews
Solve recipe clutter issue through digital curation/personalization and clean-up of recipes with no engagement
Implement recipe management tools for custom organization and scheduling

results.doc_title: IXI Results: Creator Marketplace Customer Interviews
results.summary: Research participants responded positively to HelloFresh's Influencer Marketplace concept, which addresses friction points in sourcing niche ingredients and managing saved recipes. However, trust is driven by practical signals rather than influencer status, with users expecting HelloFresh to vet recipes or provide transparent community ratings. The marketplace is viewed as occasion-based rather than everyday use, with strong preference for one-time purchases over subscriptions.
key_points: Users want food-first discovery (by ingredient/cuisine) rather than creator-led browsing
Trust requires practical signals: strong visuals, clear instructions, and links to original social media content for verification
Participants expect HelloFresh to act as a 'safety net' by vetting recipes or providing transparent reviews and ratings
Marketplace perceived as occasion-based solution for dinners, weekends, and hosting rather than everyday meal planning
Strong preference for low-commitment one-time purchases over subscription requirements
Users need robust recipe management tools including custom organization and scheduling features
4 out of 8 participants requested direct links to influencers' original social media videos on recipe pages
decisions: Need to determine if HelloFresh will quality test recipes and provide verified badges for tested content
Must decide on purchase model approach given user resistance to forced subscriptions
action_items: Include direct links to original social media videos on recipe pages
Implement verified badge system for HelloFresh-tested recipes
Create unfiltered review system with ratings, customer feedback, and photos
Add recipe comments or Q&A section separate from review system
Develop digital curation/personalization to address recipe discovery concerns
Consider clean-up mechanism for recipes with no engagement over time
Forward recipe management ideas to DAU team

results.summary: This document outlines the operational framework for working with three offshore contractor agencies: Activate Talent, Global Talent, and Hire with Near. It covers commission structures, equipment procurement processes, performance management, benefits packages, and tips for effective agency collaboration.
key_points: Three primary agencies: Activate Talent (25% commission from July 2025), Global Talent (variable commission by country), and Hire with Near (subscription-based: 25-30% with minimum $650-750/month)
Contractors should use personal IT equipment when possible; each agency has different procurement and reimbursement processes
Performance reviews include contractors with >4 months tenure; promotion decisions sit with Pets Table with C-Level involvement
Activate Talent offers 12 regular PTOs, 3 holiday PTOs, 3 sick days, 3 bereavement days, plus healthcare support
Best practices: engage at least 2 agencies, request 5-10 CVs per role, align on level/salary/skills upfront
Hire with Near has a buyout fee of 30% of annual compensation (minimum $6,000) waived after 12 months
Argentina experiencing significant currency devaluation (+43% USD to ARS in 2025) and 31.3% inflation
decisions: Activate Talent commission rate set at 25% (confidential) effective July 23rd, 2025
Global Talent reduced Bolivia commission from 33% to 31%
Contractors to use personal IT equipment where possible to avoid asset return complexities
Only employees with >4 months tenure included in performance review process
Promotion decisions sit with Pets Table, requiring C-Level discussion for contractors
Up to 3 unused PTO credits can be carried over to the next calendar year (Activate Talent)
action_items: HR BP (Abi) to manage performance review process by including contractors and sharing completed forms with agencies
Managers to inform C-Level if contractor may be promoted in next 12 months
Discuss contractor performance and promotion windows in Promotion Committee meetings (LG, DZ, AC)
Provide updated job descriptions to agencies for any promotions
Define performance review and promotion process for Near (not yet established)
Share equipment specifications with agencies when IT equipment is required

results.doc_title: 2nd iteration of new T&Cs for Activation/Reactivation
results.summary: This document outlines the second iteration of Terms & Conditions disclaimers for HelloFresh's activation/reactivation process, created in response to the upcoming FTC Negative Option Rule. The team has developed 7 proposal variations for compliant subscription disclosure language and is conducting testing and legal review to ensure compliance with new federal regulations on auto-renewing subscriptions.
key_points: FTC Negative Option Rule will dramatically expand requirements for auto-renewing subscription disclosures
Current weekly auto-renewal price is $70.93 (desktop) and $69.93 (mobile) after discount period
Cancellation must occur at least 5 days prior to next delivery/billing date
Legal counsel has reviewed proposals and provided feedback on compliance and defensibility
Rule prohibits information that 'interferes with, detracts from, contradicts, or otherwise undermines' consumer's ability to provide express informed consent
Value propositions are defensible if they relate to subscription elements/terms, not just marketing claims
Competitor benchmarking includes analysis of Marley Spoon and Amazon Prime (currently under FTC investigation)
decisions: Variation 5 FBFL would violate the draft Rule according to legal counsel
Value props relating to subscription elements are considered defensible by outside counsel
Stating 'cancel anytime' as a value prop is acceptable
Email reminders before auto-renewal are considered compliant subscription terms
Sticky CTA variation is considered compliant/defensible by outside counsel
action_items: Thomas Cohn to provide brief analysis of FTC Negative Option Rule
Thomas Cohn and Dalia Eid to determine what can be done with value propositions
Dalia Eid and Thomas Cohn to evaluate if 'slide to agree & select meals' language is acceptable
Change 'Do you Agree with our Terms & Conditions' to 'How our Subscription Work'
Change 'by clicking checkout' to 'by clicking place order & select meals'
Find markets where similar rules are already in effect for inspiration
Naseem Hasan to add example to Figma

results.doc_title: 2nd iteration of new T&Cs for Activation/Reactivation
results.summary: This document outlines the second iteration of Terms & Conditions disclaimers for HelloFresh's activation/reactivation process, created in response to the upcoming FTC Negative Option Rule. The team has developed 7 proposal variations for compliant subscription disclosure language, with legal counsel reviewing each for defensibility under the new regulations that prohibit language interfering with informed consent.
key_points: FTC Negative Option Rule will dramatically expand requirements for auto-renewing subscriptions
Current weekly auto-renewal price is $70.93 (desktop) and $69.93 (mobile) after discount period
Cancellation must occur at least 5 days prior to next delivery/billing date
Legal counsel has reviewed proposals for compliance - certain variations with value propositions violate draft rule
Value propositions are defensible only if they relate to subscription elements (e.g., 'cancel anytime', 'email reminders') not marketing claims
Competitor benchmarking includes Amazon Prime (currently under FTC investigation) and Marley Spoon
decisions: Value propositions in disclaimers must relate to subscription terms/elements, not marketing claims
Sticky CTA variation considered compliant by outside counsel
Slider mechanism variations are being explored as defensible options
Language should change from 'Do you Agree with our Terms & Conditions' to 'How our Subscription Works'
action_items: Thomas Cohn to provide brief analysis of FTC rule
Thomas Cohn and Dalia Eid to determine what can be done with value propositions
Dalia Eid and Thomas Cohn to evaluate if 'slide to agree & select meals' language is acceptable
Team to review additional variations added to document
Naseem Hasan to add Amazon example to Figma

results.doc_title: TAM Product: Context-driven Product Management Cheat Sheet
results.summary: Context-driven Product Management is a GenAI-forward framework that repositions product managers as 'context curators' rather than specification writers. It emphasizes a 'build-first' culture using AI to rapidly create prototypes and validate ideas, replacing static PRDs with dynamic, machine-readable Project Context Documents that serve as a single source of truth for both humans and AI agents.
key_points: Product managers shift from creating detailed static documentation to curating dynamic, machine-readable Project Context Documents
Framework champions 'build-first' culture with rapid prototyping over lengthy specification debates
Generative AI drastically reduces cost and time of creating prototypes, enabling faster user validation
Project Context Document becomes single source of truth guiding both human teams and AI agents
Approach moves from asking 'What should we build?' to 'What should we not choose to build?' through rapid testing
Legacy PRD-heavy processes designed for high engineering costs are now bottlenecks in the AI era
Cross-functional collaboration is promoted with shared documentation across product, engineering, and design
decisions: Move from prose-heavy, static documents to structured, machine-readable Project Context Documents
Establish clear, shared templates for structuring information for both human and machine readability
Start implementation with a single, well-defined project or pilot team before scaling
Treat adoption of this process like a product itself with iterative improvements
action_items: Define documentation standards and create robust templates for Project Context Documents
Foster culture where engineering, design, and product all contribute to maintaining the single source of truth
Begin pilot implementation on a single project or team
Gather feedback from pilot team to refine process and templates
Scale the new workflow across organization with proven best practices and internal champions

results.summary: This document outlines the governance process for discount communication presets, which are predefined fields used by marketing teams to display discount messages across various website touchpoints. The process requires coordination between product teams (who own touchpoints) and marketing teams (who manage content), with a formal notification and documentation system when new fields are added.
key_points: Discount communication presets control messaging on Landing Pages, Plans Page, Checkout, and Reactivation pages
Product teams own touchpoint placement while marketing teams handle content customization
New fields require Slack notification to #discount-communications-updates channel with specific template information
Confirmation from both NA and International P&D POCs is required before implementation
Documentation must include field descriptions, screenshots, usage guidelines, and content rules
There is confusion around field usage and potential need to separate Activation and Reactivation presets
decisions: Teams must notify via dedicated Slack channel when adding new discount communication fields
Both NA and International P&D must confirm alignment before changes proceed
Documentation updates are mandatory for all new fields
action_items: Update documentation for new fields with screenshots and usage guidelines
Consider separating Activation and Reactivation presets to reduce confusion
Clarify which fields are actively in use versus available for experimentation
Share pain points regarding Discount Communication Management (assigned to tommaso.cremonini@hellofresh.com)
Determine if certain deprecated fields can be removed or should be kept for experiments
Create visualized documentation for Reactivation input fields
